Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Reconstructing evolutionary relationships with dental microstructure

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Developing new methods for interpreting how different hominin species are related to each other becomes even more critical as more fossils are uncovered, more taxa are recognized, and the human lineage apparently displays greater species diversity. This doctoral dissertation project will examine how dental development, reflected in features of the internal microstructure of teeth, might be used to better understand the hominin family tree. Tooth sections from a wide range of living primate species will be analyzed. The project will support graduate, undergraduate, and K-12 science education, training, and outreach, including for individuals from groups that are underrepresented in the STEM fields. Data from the project will also be made available online.

A long-standing issue in paleoanthropology is the need for methods that can recover phylogenetic relationships in the hominin fossil record. Extant primates are an important comparative resource for understanding the evolutionary changes and phylogenetic relationships in the human lineage. The objectives of this project are to (1) investigate a set of traits derived from dental microstructure; (2) use phylogenetic comparative methods to determine the utility of dental microstructure variables; and (3) test these variables in an extant group of primates whose molecular phylogeny is well-established. The phylogenetic comparative analyses will help to address the extent to which dental microstructure traits carry a phylogenetic signal and therefore how these traits might be used in a phylogenetic context and applied to the hominin fossil record.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project explored the role of dental microstructure traits in primates and their role in reconstructing their evolutionary relationships. The microstructure of a tooth reveals short and long-period growth lines in the enamel and dentine, the hard tissues that make a tooth. When these short and long-period lines are quantified they can provide invaluable information regarding the time it took for an individual to grow its teeth. This has implications for other aspects of the biology of a group of animals living or dead. The shape, number, and size of these traits in the dentition can be used to determine how living and dead animals are related to each other and that was tested in this research project.

The traits in dental microstructure were assessed in the great apes, chimpanzees, gorillas, orangutans, and humans to determine how their teeth grew differently or similar. This was also assessed in more than 30 species of monkeys. The results from these two tests showed that each of the great apes is different, and perhaps the gorilla may be the most different. The monkeys also are very different from each other and the great apes. 

Assessing the levels of variation is important because previous comparative studies on the great apes have been on single individuals or small sample sizes. Trait variation is important because traits that exhibit within-taxa variation are not useful in a phylogenetic analysis, and this study showed that the majority of traits used in this analysis had higher proportions of interspecific variation. The mean differences were great enough that these traits could be useful for alpha taxonomy and phylogeny reconstruction.

Dental microstructure traits were tested for correlation with body mass and tooth size since morphological traits are highly correlated with body mass. Tooth size is highly correlated with body mass and traits such as perikymata, cuspal formation, lateral formation, cusp-specific formation time, and lateral daily secretion rate were all strongly correlated with body mass. When tooth size was tested for correlation only the traits measured in the lateral region of enamel showed a relationship. The residuals from a phylogenetic generalized least squares analysis were tested for phylogenetic signal. The lateral daily secretion rate (DSR), lateral formation time, cusp-specific formation time, cervical striae of Retzius-EDJ angle, and the lateral decussation factor showed strong signal. These traits require further study to determine whether they are conserved in primates and it would be worthwhile to increase to the study sample to test for sampling bias .

The final objective of this study was to determine whether dental microstructure traits reconstruct the primate phylogeny, used information on trait variation and phylogenetic signal of traits to reconstruct the phylogeny of extant primates. The research aims were to determine if traits with high phylogenetic signal were useful traits, and evaluate the results from using two optimality criterion, parsimony and maximum likelihood. The results from this chapter showed that the methods for testing phylogenetic signal are not contingent upon producing traits that will reconstruct a phylogeny. Phylogenetic information of an anatomical structure is only one part of the evolutionary history of the taxa in question. These analyses demonstrate that the dental microstructure traits used in this study cannot recover a primate phylogeny that is supported by molecular evidence. Focusing on only one anatomical region can also introduce a functional influence, the traits were tested for correlation with diet using a phylogenetic generalized least squares analysis since teeth are adapted for dietary specializations. There was no relationship between diet and dental microstructure traits.  

One of the major takeaway conclusions from this study, is that the data do suggest that the molecular and morphological data are not incongruous. Different lines of evidence provide different results. Perhaps we have approached phylogenetics assuming the data should provide the correct tree or hypothesis, and any deviation suggests that the data are not useful. But I would argue that there is value in every anatomical region and we must see beyond an incorrect phylogeny to what the data are telling us about the evolution of the traits within our specific sample, this will provide us with further information into understanding the evolutionary trajectory of species, especially our fossil ancestors.
